text:
Old Grand Central Station, Park Avenue at 45th Street, showing the rear of the station and the railroad tracks in the foreground, where in 1928 the New York Central Building will be erected. The view is roughly southwest from east of the future Park Avenue. The demolition of this old station and the construction of the new one will require a number of years, from about 1907 to 1912. The rear of the old station may be seen against the background of its surroundings in the New York Edison Company's photograph of Park Avenue south from 48th Street, 1903. 1872.

New York Edison Company Collection

Park Avenue north from and including 45th Street, showing the old Grand Central railroad yards, before they were electrified and covered.
Crossing the yards in the center of the picture are the 45th and 46th Street bridges.
The Liberty Storage warehouse is at the S.W. corner of 50th Street and Park Avenue.
Opposite it, on the south side of 50th Street, is the old Women's Hospital, shortly to be demolished.
Immediately south of it is the old Adams Express building.
Going north on the east side of Park Avenue F. & M. Schaefer's Brewery is between 50th and 51st streets, and the Steinway Piano factory between 52nd and 53rd Streets, both dating, at least in part, from the 1850's.
Compare this with Galloway's Photograph of the same scene in the winter of 1923-24, also with Park Avenue north from 46th Street in 1913.
1903.

Park Avenue, north from and including 45th Street, showing the buildings on the east side of the Avenue, seen from the roof of the Grand Central Station, which appears in the center foreground.

The area over the railroad yards is still open on the east side from 45th to 46th Streets and from 47th to 48th Streets, and on the west side from 45th to 47th Streets. The nearest building on the west side is the Hotel Marguery (about 1917) from 47th to 45th Streets.

On the east side 247 Park Avenue, completed about 1922, and connected to the new Grand Central Palace in the Lexington Avenue half of the block, stands from 46th to 47th Streets. In the block from 48th to 49th Streets the new Park Lane apartment hotel may be seen under construction, and in the block directly north of it the Railroad Y.M.C.A. building, which is to be demolished in 1929 to make way for the new Waldorf-Astoria. These buildings hid St. Bartholomew's Church, so that the next visible building on the east side is the Hotel Ambassador (1910-20), on the block from 51st to 52nd Streets.

To the right of the picture may be seen the new American Express Building from 45th to 46th Streets on Lexington Avenue, and behind it the tower of the Hotel Shelton, nearing completion, on the east side of Lexington Avenue from 47th to 48th Streets.

On the horizon, dimly seen at the extreme right, is the Hell Gate Bridge, shown surprisingly large considering its actual distance.

Compare this with the same scene in 1903.

Winter 1923-4

Ewing Galloway, Photographer.

Park Avenue, north from 46th Street, seen from 45th Street. The building under construction at the left is the new Postum Building at 46th Street.

June 1924.

P.L. Sperr, Photographer.

Park Avenue, west side, from 46th to 45th Streets, showing the site of the New York Central Building, 230 Park Avenue, as construction begins on it. In the right background are shown the Vanderbilt Concourse Building, the Yale Club (50 Vanderbilt Avenue), and the Hotel Biltmore. The Grand Central Terminal cuts off Park Avenue at 45th Street.

October 2, 1927.

P. L. Sperr.

Park Avenue, west side; 45th to 47th Streets, showing the Postum Building at 250 Park Avenue across the space in the foreground where the New York Central Building is to be erected; construction on the latter is beginning. The view is from 45th Street east of Park Avenue.

October 11, 1927.

P. L. Sperr.

The north side of the New York Central Building, 45th Street, south side, at Park Avenue, which passes underneath the building.

About 1928.

Wide World.

New York Central Building, 230 Park Avenue, 45th to 46th Streets, a rear view during the later stages of construction. 1928.

Ewing Galloway.

title: Park Avenue - 45th Street, east side - looking north

text:
230 Park Avenue, from E. 45th to 46th Streets, as viewed north-westward from the Chrysler Building at 42nd Street. This address is that of the New York Central Building of which a rear perspective is shown. In the background across same appear the blocks of brown stone dwellings where the present Rockefeller Center (Radio City) emerged. Note the twin spires of St. Patrick's Cathedral to the east of same.

1930.

Ewing Galloway.

(1) Park Ave., west side, south from and including East 54th to and including 45th Streets.

P. L. Sperr.

August 13, 1936.

(2) The same, from a point slightly northward, showing (left background) the New York Central Building on East 45th Street, which breaks-up the continuity of Park Ave. Traffic passes around this building and through the arched openings to resume its course southward on Park Ave. at East 41st Street. The fenced in block (from East 54th to East 53rd Streets) seen in view No. 1 is now occupied by a 1-story building to be used for stores.

P. L. Sperr.

February 7, 1937.

(1) Park Ave., west side, south from and including East 54th to and including 45th Streets.

P. L. Sperr.

August 13, 1936.

(2) The same, from a point slightly northward, showing (left background) the New York Central Building on East 45th Street, which breaks-up the continuity of Park Ave. Traffic passes around this building and through the arched openings to resume its course southward on Park Ave. at East 41st Street. The fenced in block (from East 54th to East 53rd Streets) seen in view No. 1 is now occupied by a 1-story building to be used for stores.

P. L. Sperr.

February 7, 1937.
